questions.text: A hospital has reported an outbreak of MRSA infection. On investigation, it was found out that a staff nurse had nasal carriage of MRSA. Which of the following drugs helps in the removal of colonization of bacteria? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Topical mupirocin

 

Topical mupirocin is the preferred agent for the elimination of nasal carriers of MRSA.

 

Decolonization therapy is the administration of antimicrobial or antiseptic agents to eradicate or suppress MRSA carriage:

 

  • Intranasal antibiotic or antiseptic (e.g., mupirocin, povidone-iodine)
  • Topical antiseptic (e.g., chlorhexidine)
  • +/- Systemic antibiotics

 

MRSA decolonization has been associated with reduction in MRSA carriage, transmission and infection.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral vancomycin: While effective against MRSA, oral vancomycin is not used for nasal decolonization. It is primarily used for treating severe systemic MRSA infections and Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea.

 

Option B. Inj cephalosporin: Cephalosporins are a class of antibiotics that are generally ineffective against MRSA due to resistance mechanisms. They are not used for MRSA nasal decolonization.

 

Option D. Inhaled colistin: Colistin is an antibiotic used for treating multidrug-resistant Gram-negative infections, particularly in the lungs. It is not used for nasal decolonization of MRSA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topical mupirocin is the recommended treatment for the nasal decolonization of MRSA, effectively reducing the nasal carriage of the bacteria and thereby decreasing the risk of transmission and subsequent infections.

questions.text:
What are the components of Nada's Minor Criteria? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Systolic mumur Grade 3
  2. Diastolic murmur
  3. Abnormal second heart sound
  4. Abnormal BP
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 and 4

 

Nada’s criteria is used for detection of CHD on the basis of clinical evaluation.

 

 

Presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria suggest presence of heart disease.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In Nada’s criteria for detecting congenital heart disease, minor criteria include an abnormal second heart sound and abnormal blood pressure. The presence of one major or two minor criteria suggests the presence of heart disease.

questions.text: Which of the following does not play a role in fetal growth?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Growth hormone

 

Growth hormone (GH) does not play a significant role in fetal growth. The primary regulators of fetal growth are insulin-like growth factors (IGFs) and thyroxine. IGFs are critical for cellular growth and differentiation during fetal development. Thyroxine, a thyroid hormone, is essential for brain development and overall growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Insulin-like growth factors: These play a crucial role in fetal growth by promoting cellular growth and differentiation.

 

Option C. Thyroxine: This hormone is vital for proper development, particularly for brain development and metabolic regulation.

 

Option D. All of the above: This option is incorrect because growth hormone does not significantly influence fetal growth, while IGFs and thyroxine do.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth hormone does not play a significant role in fetal growth, while insulin-like growth factors and thyroxine are crucial for proper fetal development.

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of fever, rash, body ache, and throat ache. He has a history of thorn prick injury a week back. What antibiotics would you give empirically to this child? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amoxicilin +clavulanate

 

The symptoms described in this case—fever, rash, sore throat, and body aches—following a thorn prick injury suggest the possibility of scarlet fever caused by Group A Streptococcus (GAS). Scarlet fever typically presents with a diffuse erythematous rash, which may be papular, along with other symptoms such as a sore throat, body aches, and the characteristic "strawberry tongue."

 

Key Points:

 

  • Scarlet Fever and GAS: Scarlet fever is most commonly caused by GAS and is characterized by the production of pyrogenic (erythrogenic) exotoxin, leading to the rash and other systemic symptoms.
  • Empirical Antibiotic Treatment:
    • Amoxicillin + Clavulanate: This combination is a first-line treatment for infections caused by GAS, particularly when there is a concern for beta-lactamase-producing bacteria. Clavulanate inhibits beta-lactamase enzymes, allowing amoxicillin to remain effective against the bacteria.
    • Penicillin or Amoxicillin alone is generally the treatment of choice for scarlet fever, but adding clavulanate broadens the spectrum to cover potential mixed infections.
  • Diagnostic Confirmation: While empirical treatment is initiated, a rapid antigen detection test or throat culture for Streptococcus should be performed to confirm the diagnosis of GAS infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that is typically reserved for more severe infections requiring hospitalization. It is not the first choice for uncomplicated scarlet fever.

 

Option C. Vancomycin. and Option D. Meropenem: These are higher-tier antibiotics reserved for severe or resistant infections, often guided by culture and sensitivity results. They are not typically used as first-line treatment in cases of suspected scarlet fever or mild GAS infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a child presenting with symptoms suggestive of scarlet fever following a thorn prick injury, empirical antibiotic treatment with amoxicillin + clavulanate is appropriate while awaiting diagnostic confirmation of Group A Streptococcus infection.

questions.text: Which muscle is not involved in the inversion of foot? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Peroneus longus

 

The peroneus longus is a muscle of the lateral compartment of the leg. It originates from the head and upper two-thirds of the fibula, and it has a long tendon that wraps behind the lateral malleolus and extends to the medial side of the foot, inserting into the base of the first metatarsal and medial cuneiform. When the peroneus longus contracts, it everts the foot and also plantarflexes the ankle. Therefore, the peroneus longus is not involved in the inversion of the foot.

 

Inversion of the foot is a movement in which the medial border of the foot is elevated so that the sole faces medially.

 

  • Tibialis anterior - Dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot
  • Tibialis posterior - Plantar flexion and inversion of the foot
  • Extensor hallucis longs - Extension of the great toe, dorsiflexion of the foot, and inversion of the foot (minimal action)

 

Eversion of the foot is a movement where the lateral border of the foot is elevated so that the sole faces laterally.

 

  • Peroneus longus, peroneus brevis, and peroneus tertius are the muscles involved.

 

These movements take place, mainly at the talocalcaneal and the talocalcaneonavicular joints, and partly at the transverse tarsal joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tibialis anterior: The tibialis anterior is a muscle of the anterior compartment of the leg. It originates from the lateral surface of the tibia and inserts into the medial cuneiform and first metatarsal bones of the foot. When this muscle contracts, it dorsiflexes the ankle (pulls the foot upwards, towards the shin) and inverts the foot. Therefore, the tibialis anterior plays a role in foot inversion.

 

Option B. Tibialis posterior: The tibialis posterior is located in the deep compartment of the leg. It originates from the posterior surfaces of the tibia and fibula and inserts into various bones in the foot, including the navicular, cuneiforms, and metatarsals. When the tibialis posterior contracts, it plantarflexes the ankle (points the foot downward) and also inverts the foot. Like the tibialis anterior, the tibialis posterior is involved in foot inversion.

 

Option D. Extensor hallucis longus: The extensor hallucis longus is another muscle of the anterior compartment of the leg. It originates from the anterior surface of the fibula and the interosseous membrane and inserts into the distal phalanx of the big toe. Its primary action is to dorsiflex the big toe. While it plays a role in dorsiflexion of the ankle, its contribution to inversion or eversion is minimal compared to the other muscles listed. However, it can assist in inversion to a minor extent when combined with other inverters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peroneus longus muscle is not involved in the inversion of the foot. It causes eversion and plantar flexion.

 

The transverse tarsal joint and the talocalcaneal and talocalcaneonavicular joints also play a role in inversion and eversion movements

questions.text: Adrenocorticotropic hormone is the drug of choice in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) West syndrome

 

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice in West syndrome.

 

  • West syndrome is a severe generalised epilepsy that begins between the ages of 2 and 12 months. It is characterized by a triad of:
    • Infantile spasm
    • Developmental regression
    • Hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalogram (EEG)

 

Hypsarrhythmia refers to a high voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes.

 

Treatment of West syndrome includes:

 

  • ACTH
  • Vigabatrin when associated with tuberous sclerosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy: Young adults who have juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME) commonly experience myoclonic jerks in the morning. Valproate is helpful in treating benign myoclonic epilepsy, whereas levetiracetam is helpful in treating severe myoclonic epilepsies.

 

Option B. Rolandic epilepsy: Rolandic epilepsy is benign epilepsy seen in children. They present at night or while awakening.

 

Option D. Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS): Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS) is a rare but severe form of childhood epilepsy characterized by a triad of multiple seizure types, characteristic EEG findings, and intellectual impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice in West syndrome.

choices.text: There is hypertrophy of ductus arteriosus.
Coarctation distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery
Supply is from posterior to anterior thoracic artery.
Collaterals develop to supply upper limb.

questions.text: A child presents with cold feet and a history of wearing socks even in the summers. On examination, lower limb pulses are diminished as compared to the radial pulse. Prominent radio femoral delay is present. What is the underlying condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coarctation distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery

 

The clinical presentation of cold feet, wearing socks even in summer, diminished lower limb pulses compared to radial pulses, and prominent radiofemoral delay is characteristic of coarctation of the aorta. This congenital condition is characterized by a narrowing (coarctation) of the aorta, typically just distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery at the ductus arteriosus.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Coarctation of the Aorta: This condition results in the obstruction of blood flow, leading to higher blood pressure in the upper limbs and lower blood pressure in the lower limbs. The radiofemoral delay is a classic sign.
  • Location of Coarctation:
    • Postductal Coarctation (Adult Type): The constriction occurs distal to the ductus arteriosus. This type is more common and leads to the development of collateral circulation to bypass the obstruction.
    • Predductal Coarctation (Infantile Type): The constriction occurs proximal to the ductus arteriosus, leading to different clinical features and often presenting in infancy.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Cold feet and preference for wearing socks may be due to poor perfusion in the lower extremities.
    • Diminished lower limb pulses and radiofemoral delay are hallmark signs.
    • Hypertension in the upper extremities due to the coarctation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertrophy of ductus arteriosus: This condition does not cause radiofemoral delay or the constellation of symptoms seen in coarctation of the aorta.

 

Option C. Supply from posterior to anterior thoracic artery: This does not explain the clinical presentation, especially the radiofemoral delay.

 

Option D. Collaterals develop to supply upper limb: Collateral circulation is a compensatory mechanism that develops over time in coarctation of the aorta, primarily to supply blood to the lower extremities, not just the upper limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarctation of the aorta typically presents with cold feet, diminished lower limb pulses, and radiofemoral delay due to a narrowing of the aorta distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery.

questions.text: Which alternative method can be used for the procedure shown in the image below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arm span

 

The image shows the measurement of a child's height using a stadiometer. The alternative method that can be used for measuring height is arm span. The arm span is a measurement from the tip of one middle finger to the tip of the other middle finger when the arms are outstretched horizontally. This measurement is typically close to the child's height and can be used as an alternative method, especially in cases where the child is unable to stand properly.

 

The proportion of arm span to height changes with age but is generally close to the height measurement. In clinical practice, when direct measurement of height is not feasible, arm span can be a reliable surrogate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head circumference: Head circumference is measured using a measuring tape and is an important metric in assessing brain growth and development, especially in infants and young children, but it is not an alternative for height measurement.

 

Option C. Crown-rump length: Crown-rump length is a measurement used during an ultrasound in early pregnancy to estimate the gestational age of the fetus, not a method for height measurement in children.

 

Option D. Knee height: Knee height is not typically used for measuring height in children and is more often used in adults, particularly the elderly, to estimate height when they are unable to stand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arm span can be used as an alternative method for measuring height, especially when direct height measurement is not feasible.

questions.text:
Which of the following are causes of neonatal seizures? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Hyponatremia
  2. Hypomagnesemia
  3. Hypocalcemia
  4. Hypernatremia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3 and 4

 

All of the above-given options- hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, and hypernatremia are causes of neonatal seizures.

 

Metabolic disorders cause neonatal seizures commonly. Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy is the most common cause.

 

 

Neonatal seizures may be of five types: subtle, tonic, clonic, spasms, and myoclonic.

 

  • Subtle seizures include movements like transient eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing, rowing, cycling, pedaling, fluctuations in heart rate, hypertension episodes, and apnea. They are more common in premature than in term babies.
  • Tonic seizures are characterized by increased tension in the muscle groups. They may be focal or generalized.
    • Focal tonic seizures are characterized by sustained posturing of a single limb, sustained asymmetrical posturing of the trunk, and sustained eye deviation. They can not be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.
    • Generalized tonic seizures occur as bilateral tonic limb extensions or flexions of the upper limbs often accompanied by a tonic extension of the lower limbs and trunk.
  • A clonic seizure is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups. Muscles of the limbs, face, or trunk can be involved. They can be unifocal or multifocal. It cannot be suppressed by restraint.
  • Spasms are sudden generalized jerks lasting 1-2 sec and are usually associated with a single, very brief, generalized discharge. They may be flexor, extensor, or mixed extensor/flexor and can occur in clusters. It cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.
  • Myoclonic seizures can be focal, multifocal, or generalized. They are differentiated from clonic seizures by their lack of rhythmicity and the rapidity of the jerks (<50 msec).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonatal seizures can be caused by various metabolic disturbances, including hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, and hypernatremia, and these should be considered in the differential diagnosis of seizures in neonates.

questions.text: All of the following are the core clinical features for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Orthostatic hypotension.

 

Lewy body dementia (LBD), also known as dementia with Lewy bodies, is characterized by specific core clinical features. Orthostatic hypotension, while commonly observed in LBD due to autonomic dysfunction, is not classified as a core clinical feature but rather as a supportive feature for diagnosis.

 

Central feature: Dementia (Essential for the diagnosis of DLB).

 

Core Clinical criteria include the following:

 

  1. Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness.
  2. Recurrent visual hallucinations that are typically well formed and detailed.
  3. Rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder (RBD).
  4. Spontaneous cardinal features of parkinsonism.

 

Supportive Features of LBD:

 

  • Autonomic Dysfunction: Including orthostatic hypotension.
  • Severe Sensitivity to Antipsychotic Drugs: Patients may experience severe motor and neuroleptic sensitivity.
  • Other Hallucinations and Neurological Signs: Can include auditory hallucinations or transient, unexplained loss of consciousness.

 

Onset of dementia preceding or within 1 year of onset of parkinsonism differentiates Lewy Body dementia from Parkinson's disease with dementia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluctuating cognition: Fluctuating cognition is one of the hallmark symptoms of LBD, characterized by significant variations in attention and alertness. This fluctuation is more pronounced than what is typically seen in other forms of dementia, such as Alzheimer's disease, and can vary from hour to hour or day to day.

 

Option B. REM sleep behavior disorder: REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD) is a core feature of LBD, where patients physically act out their dreams, often vividly. This disorder is a result of the loss of normal muscle atonia that should occur during REM sleep, leading to potentially violent movements and vocalizations during sleep.

 

Option C. Recurrent visual hallucinations: Visual hallucinations in LBD are typically well-formed and detailed, often involving people or animals. These hallucinations are a core feature and differ from the more nebulous or less structured hallucinations seen in other disorders. They are thought to be due to the underlying Lewy body pathology affecting cortical brain areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orthostatic hypotension is a supportive, not core, criterion for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia.

 

Reference - Harrison 21e/Neurology, DLB Chapter 434 /12305.

questions.text:
A 9-month-old boy presents with progressive pallor and abdominal distension. The peripheral smear done is as shown below, and the Mentzer index was found to be less than 13. What are the investigations to be done in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC)
  2. PT and APTT
  3. Bone marrow
  4. Peripheral blood smear
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 4

 

The clinical presentation, along with the findings of the peripheral blood smear and a Mentzer index of less than 13, suggests a diagnosis of thalassemia.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Thalassemia: A hemoglobinopathy characterized by a deficiency in the synthesis of one of the globin chains, either alpha or beta. In beta-thalassemia, there is reduced synthesis of beta chains, leading to decreased levels of hemoglobin A (HbA) and increased levels of HbA2 and HbF.
  • High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC): This test is crucial for diagnosing thalassemia as it can detect changes in hemoglobin levels, specifically the increased levels of HbA2 and HbF that are characteristic of beta-thalassemia. HPLC is sufficient for diagnosis without the need for bone marrow investigations.
  • Peripheral Blood Smear: The smear may reveal aniso-poikilocytosis, target cells, basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells, which are indicative of thalassemia.
  • Mentzer Index: The Mentzer index, calculated as MCV/RBC count, helps differentiate thalassemia from iron-deficiency anemia. A value of less than 13 suggests thalassemia, while a value greater than 13 suggests iron-deficiency anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

2 (PT and APTT): These tests are not directly relevant for the diagnosis of thalassemia. PT (Prothrombin Time) is used to assess the extrinsic pathway of coagulation, and APTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time) assesses the intrinsic pathway, typically done when bleeding disorders are suspected.

 

3 (Bone Marrow): Bone marrow examination is not necessary in this case as the diagnosis of thalassemia can be made based on HPLC and peripheral smear findings. Bone marrow investigations are more appropriate for cases of pancytopenia or unexplained anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child suspected of having thalassemia, High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) and a peripheral blood smear are key investigations for diagnosis.

questions.text: Enzyme deficient in pompe’s disease is: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha 1, 4 glucosidase

 

  • Pompe's disease is caused by a deficiency of alpha-1,4-glucosidase (also known as acid maltase), an enzyme involved in the breakdown of glycogen. Pompe's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly in muscles.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Glucose 6 phosphatase: This is not the correct enzyme. Glucose 6 phosphatase deficiency is associated with von Gierke's disease, a glycogen storage disorder. It primarily affects the liver and kidney.

 

Option C. Muscle phosphorylase: Muscle phosphorylase is associated with McArdle's disease, a glycogen storage disorder affecting skeletal muscles. It is not the enzyme deficient in Pompe's disease.

 

Option D. Phosphofructokinase: Phosphofructokinase is associated with Tarui's disease, another glycogen storage disorder. It is not the enzyme deficient in Pompe's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the enzymatic basis of Pompe's disease, recognizing that it is caused by a deficiency of alpha-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase). Be aware of the clinical manifestations and biochemical abnormalities associated with Pompe's disease, which is characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly in muscles.

questions.text: Most common organism for croup? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Influenza virus

 

Croup, also known as laryngotracheobronchitis, is an acute viral infection primarily affecting the larynx and trachea in children. The most common causative organism is the parainfluenza virus (particularly types 1 and 2), followed by influenza viruses. 

 

Laryngotracheobronchitis (CROUP)

 

  • Viral infection of glottis & subglottic region 
  • Caused by parainfluenza virus 
  • Symptoms: hoarse voice, coryza, mild tachypnea 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haemophilus influenzae: This is a bacterial organism that can cause epiglottitis and other respiratory infections. It is not a common cause of croup.


 

Option B. Streptococcus: This bacterial organism (particularly group A streptococcus) commonly causes pharyngitis ("strep throat") but is not a typical cause of croup.

 

Option D. Diphtheria: Caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, this bacterial infection can affect the respiratory tract but typically produces a pseudomembrane in the throat rather than the classic croup symptoms. Diphtheria has become rare in countries with routine immunization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viral pathogens, particularly parainfluenza virus and influenza virus, as the most common causative agents of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis) in children.

questions.text:
A child is brought to the casualty with a history of choking. On examination, there is decreased air entry in the left lung. What would be the correct management? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Bronchoscopy
  2. Computed tomography scan
  3. ICD insertion
  4. Chest x-ray
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 4

 

A child presenting with a history of choking and decreased air entry in the left lung is highly suggestive of a foreign body lodged in the left bronchus. The correct management steps include:

 

1. Bronchoscopy: This is the gold standard for both the diagnosis and removal of the foreign body. Rigid bronchoscopy is typically performed by a specialist, such as an otolaryngologist or pulmonologist, to visualize and extract the foreign body.

 

4. Chest X-ray: This is an essential initial investigation to assess for the presence of a foreign body. Although many foreign bodies are radiolucent, secondary findings such as air trapping, obstructive emphysema, atelectasis, asymmetric hyperinflation, mediastinal shift, and consolidation can be indicative of foreign body aspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

2. CT scan: While a CT scan has high sensitivity and specificity for detecting radiolucent foreign bodies, it is not routinely performed in this situation due to the high radiation exposure, especially in children.

 

3. ICD insertion: Insertion of an intercostal drain (ICD) is not indicated unless there is clinical evidence of pneumothorax or other complications that require it. A chest X-ray is essential before deciding on this intervention.

 

Clinical Approach:

 

  • A detailed history and physical examination are critical when a child presents with choking.
  • A chest X-ray should be performed to assess for secondary signs of foreign body aspiration.
  • Bronchoscopy should be conducted even if imaging is negative but clinical suspicion remains high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child with suspected foreign body aspiration, a chest X-ray and bronchoscopy are the key steps for diagnosis and management. Bronchoscopy allows for both visualization and removal of the foreign body.

questions.text: INSURE technique is used in newborn, born with which condition?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyaline membrane disease

 

The INSURE technique stands for INtubate, SURfactant, and Extubate. This method is used primarily in the management of preterm infants with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), also known as hyaline membrane disease. The procedure involves:

 

  1. Intubating the newborn to establish a secure airway.
  2. Administering surfactant directly into the lungs to reduce surface tension and improve lung function.
  3. Extubating the newborn after the surfactant has been given to allow for spontaneous breathing with the aid of non-invasive ventilation, if necessary.

 

Hyaline membrane disease occurs in preterm infants due to the immaturity of the lungs and a deficiency of surfactant, a substance that prevents the alveoli in the lungs from collapsing. The INSURE technique is effective in providing the necessary surfactant and reducing the severity of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meconium aspiration syndrome: This option is incorrect because meconium aspiration syndrome occurs in post-term infants who inhale meconium-stained amniotic fluid, leading to respiratory distress. The INSURE technique is not used for this condition.

 

Option B. Transiente tachypnea of newborn: This option is incorrect because transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN) is a self-limited condition seen in term infants caused by delayed clearance of fetal lung fluid. It typically resolves without the need for surfactant administration.

 

Option D. Neonatal jaundice: This option is incorrect because neonatal jaundice, caused by elevated bilirubin levels, is not related to lung function or surfactant deficiency. The INSURE technique is not applicable to this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The INSURE technique (Intubate, Surfactant, Extubate) is primarily used in preterm infants with hyaline membrane disease to administer surfactant and improve lung function.

questions.text:
What are the recommended actions according to Neonatal Resuscitation guidelines for a baby born with meconium-stained amniotic fluid? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. lntrapartum suction of nose and mouth before delivery of shoulder
  2. lntratracheal suction in case of non-vigorous baby
  3. Gentle suction of nose and mouth in case of vigorous baby
  4. PPV in case of non-vigorous baby after early steps
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4


According to the Neonatal Resuscitation guidelines, the recommended actions for a newborn with meconium-stained amniotic fluid are as follows:

 

4. For a non-vigorous baby (poor muscle tone, weak or absent respiratory effort, or heart rate <100 bpm): The baby should receive positive pressure ventilation (PPV) following initial resuscitation steps. The current guidelines recommend PPV over routine intratracheal suctioning in non-vigorous infants because studies have shown that routine suctioning does not improve outcomes and may delay necessary resuscitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 2, 3, 4: Intrapartum suction of the nose and mouth before delivery of the shoulders and routine intratracheal suctioning are no longer recommended in the current guidelines.

 

Option B. 2, 4: While PPV is recommended for non-vigorous infants, routine intratracheal suctioning is not indicated.

 

Option D. 1, 3, 4: Intrapartum suction is not recommended under the current guidelines.

 

Educational Objective:
 

For a newborn with meconium-stained amniotic fluid, PPV is administered if the baby is non-vigorous after the initial steps of resuscitation.

questions.text: What is the fluid of choice in pediatric patients?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DNS

 

DNS (Dextrose Normal Saline) is the fluid of choice in pediatric patients. It contains 5% dextrose along with normal saline (0.9% sodium chloride). This combination helps to provide both hydration and glucose, which is essential for energy. Additionally, DNS can help maintain electrolyte balance, which is critical in pediatric patients who are often at risk for dehydration and electrolyte imbalances. In practice, 1 ml of potassium chloride (KCl) is often added to every 100 ml of DNS to ensure adequate potassium levels, which are vital for proper cellular function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RL (Ringer's Lactate): Ringer's Lactate is often used for fluid resuscitation in adults and in specific conditions such as acidosis. However, it does not contain dextrose, which is necessary for pediatric patients for energy and maintaining blood glucose levels.

 

Option C. NS (Normal Saline): Normal Saline (0.9% sodium chloride) is useful for hydration and electrolyte balance but lacks dextrose. Pediatric patients need a source of glucose, especially in cases of prolonged fasting or illness, making NS alone less suitable than DNS.

 

Option D. 5% dextrose: 5% dextrose provides glucose but lacks the electrolytes found in saline. This can lead to imbalances, particularly in pediatric patients, where maintaining proper electrolyte levels is crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fluid of choice in pediatric patients is DNS (Dextrose Normal Saline), which provides essential hydration, electrolytes, and glucose for energy.

questions.text: Child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be Zellweger syndrome. Which among the following accumulates in brain in this condition?(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Long chain fatty acid

 

Zellweger syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder. It occurs due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA). Peroxisomal enzymes are produced; but their entry into peroxisome is denied. This leads to insufficient oxidation of VLCFA. Accumulation of VLCFA in CNS causes neurological impairment and death in childhood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose:

  • Function: Primary energy source for the brain.
  • Relevance: Accumulation is not characteristic of Zellweger syndrome but is more relevant in conditions like glycogen storage diseases or diabetes.

 

Option B. Lactic acid:

  • Function: Produced during anaerobic metabolism.
  • Relevance: Accumulation is associated with mitochondrial disorders or lactic acidosis, not Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option D. Triglycerides:

  • Function: Stored form of energy in adipose tissue.
  • Relevance: Accumulation in the brain is not characteristic of Zellweger syndrome; rather, it is associated with lipid storage diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zellweger syndrome leads to the accumulation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) in the brain due to defective peroxisomal oxidation, resulting in severe neurological impairment and early death in affected children.

choices.text: Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

questions.text: A child presents with fever and vesicular lesions on the upper limb and the lower limb. Neck stiffness was present. Similar lesions were present on the palms, soles, and oral cavity. CSF analysis revealed normal glucose levels and elevated lymphocytes and protein. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

 

The clinical vignette and images provided suggest HFMD meningitis.

 

The presence of vesicular lesions on the palms, soles, and oral cavity, as well as images of the lesions, suggest Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD). The presence of neck stiffness, as well as CSF with normal glucose levels, elevated lymphocytes, and protein levels, suggests viral meningitis.

 

Therefore the best answer is - Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

 

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease:

 

Causes:

 

  • Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is commonly caused by coxsackievirus A16 which is a subgroup of enteroviruses.
  • In large outbreaks, other enteroviruses like enterovirus71, coxsackie A viruses 5,6,7,9, 10 and coxsackie B virus 2 and 5 may also cause HFMD.

 

Clinical features: HFMD is often a minor condition.

 

  • The tongue, posterior pharynx, buccal mucosa, palate, lips, etc. may all have vesicular lesions.
  • Lesions that are maculopapular, vesicular, or pustular may appear on the hands, fingers, buttocks, or groin.
  • Compared to the feet, lesions are more frequently found on the hands.
  • These vesicles disappear within a week.
  • Enterovirus 71 infections are more serious and are linked to cardiovascular and neurological symptoms.
  • Complications from coxsackievirus A16 infections might occasionally include shock, encephalitis, acute flaccid paralysis, and myocarditis.
  • A severe variant of HFMD called atypical HFMD is caused by coxsackievirus A6.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • HFMD is usually diagnosed clinically by the characteristic lesions.
  • Viral culture can be done to confirm the presence of enterovirus. Blood, CSF, urine, and mucosal swabs can be cultured.
  • RT-PCR testing to detect the viral genome is more sensitive and specific.
  • PCR testing of CSF in children with meningitis is frequently positive even when the cultures are negative.

 

Treatment:

 

  • No specific antiviral agent is proven to be effective against enteroviruses. Supportive care is the mainstay of treatment.
  • Milrinone is suggested as an effective agent for enterovirus 71 cardiopulmonary disease.
  • Immunoglobulins have been used to manage severe cases but with varying outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis with sepsis: Bacterial meningitis with sepsis is not a likely differential diagnosis for vesicular lesions with this distribution. HSV encephalitis manifests with typical findings of injury to the frontal or parietal cortex or limbic system, including anosmia, memory loss, focal seizures, expressive aphasia, and peculiar behaviour.

 

Option C. Herpes simplex gingivostomatitis and meningoencephalitis: Despite having vesicular lesions, meningoencephalitis and herpes simplex gingivostomatitis show differently clinically. High-grade fever, rapid onset of excruciating mouth pain, and saliva dribbling are the symptoms of HSV gingivostomatitis.

 

Option D. Tuberculous meningitis: Tuberculous meningitis is improbable given the absence of a history of exposure to TB. CSF results in bacterial meningitis often include reduced glucose and raised neutrophils and protein levels. In most cases, CSF results in tuberculous meningitis demonstrate decreased glucose and high amount

 

The majority of the time, CSF results in tuberculous meningitis demonstrate decreased glucose levels, increased lymphocytes, and protein levels.

 

  • Other possible differentials for vesicular lesions include hand-foot-and-mouth disease, varicella (chickenpox), and herpangina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coxsackie viral infection can cause Hand-foot-and-mouth disease with associated viral meningitis, characterized by vesicular lesions on the palms, soles, and oral cavity, along with normal glucose and elevated lymphocytes in CSF.

questions.text: In neonatal resuscitation, which of the following is the most effective indicator of successful ventilatory effort? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rise in heart rate.

 

An increase in heart rate is the best sign that a ventilatory effort is working.

 

When newborns are unable to breathe on their own, positive pressure ventilation, or PP, is used. To ensure that the airway is open, the infant's neck is slightly stretched in this position. An appropriate-sized face mask is chosen so that it may cover the mouth and nose when the care provider is at the baby's head end. For a good seal, it should be gripped firmly, and compression is applied using the fingers.

 

Visible chest rise is a sign of adequate ventilation, and ventilation should be initiated when normal chest rise is seen.

 

The baby's progress is measured by an increase in heart rate, spontaneous breathing, and improvement in colour.

 

When there is no rise in heart rate, ventilation corrective steps should be taken. It is as follows

 

  • Mask has to be reapplied
  • The infant's head is repositioned
  • Suction the secretions
  • The mouth is kept open slightly and ventilated. Also, the pressure is increased slightly.
  • Change the airway

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colour change: Colour change is a component of APGAR score

 

Option C. Air entry: Air entry is checked during intubation to check weather the endotracheal tube is in centre which gives equal air entry to both lungs.

 

Option D. Chest rise: Chest rise is also seen once we do bag and mask ventilation but the most important indicator is rising heart rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In neonatal resuscitation, rise in heart rate is the most effective indicator of successful ventilatory effort.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Kawasaki disease?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Purulent conjunctivitis


Kawasaki disease is a medium vessel vasculitis that typically affects children and involves several characteristic features. The mnemonic "REEMA" helps remember these features:

 

  • R for Rash: Patients with Kawasaki disease often have a polymorphous rash.
  • E for Edema: Edema of the hands and feet is common in Kawasaki disease.
  • E for Eyes: Patients have non-purulent conjunctivitis, which is a hallmark of the disease.
  • M for Mucosal involvement: Mucosal changes include a strawberry tongue and cracked lips.
  • A for Adenopathy: Cervical lymphadenopathy is a typical feature.
  • Patients also exhibit prolonged fever lasting more than five days.
  • Thrombocytosis (increased platelet count) is another feature of Kawasaki disease during the subacute phase.

 

Purulent conjunctivitis, which involves a discharge of pus, is not a feature of Kawasaki disease. Instead, patients typically have non-purulent conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:


Non-purulent conjunctivitis is a feature of Kawasaki disease, whereas purulent conjunctivitis is not.

choices.text: Compression to ventilation ratio should be 30:2 with 2 rescuers
Chest compression depth should be one-third of A-P diameter of chest
Injection Adenosine 0.01 ml/kg IV or IO (1:10,000)

questions.text: All of the following are incorrect about resuscitation of a critically sick child, except? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chest compression depth should be one-third of A-P diameter of chest

 

In pediatric advanced life support and resuscitation, the chest compression depth for pediatric patients should be one-third of the anterior-posterior (A-P) diameter of the chest. This ensures adequate cardiac output without causing injury to internal structures. For children, this typically translates to approximately 5 cm (2 inches) or about one-third of the chest diameter, which allows for effective cardiac compression while minimizing the risk of trauma to underlying organs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preferred route of adrenaline intraosseous: This statement is incorrect. While the intraosseous (IO) route is a valuable alternative when intravenous access cannot be established quickly, the preferred route for adrenaline administration is intravenous (IV). The drug has a very short half-life and is most effective when administered through a central or large peripheral vein, followed by a saline flush. 

 

Option B. Compression to ventilation ratio should be 30:2 with 2 rescuers: This statement is incorrect for pediatric resuscitation. In children, with 2 rescuers, the recommended compression to ventilation ratio is 15:2. The 30:2 ratio is used either for adult resuscitation or for single-rescuer pediatric resuscitation.

 

Option D. Injection Adenosine 0.01 ml/kg IV or IO (1:10,000): This statement is incorrect regarding the dosing of adenosine. The correct dose of adenosine for children is 0.1 mg/kg (maximum first dose 6 mg) with subsequent doses of 0.2 mg/kg (maximum 12 mg). 

 

Educational Objective: 


Chest compression depth for pediatric resuscitation as one-third of the anterior-posterior diameter of the chest, while recognizing incorrect statements about medication routes and compression-to-ventilation ratios.

questions.text: At what age does a child attain half-height of the adult height? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20-24 months

 

  • Children attain half of their adult height by the age of 20-24 months.
  • For children under 2 years of age, length is measured with the help of  an infantometer or rigid measuring table. The infant's head is held firmly against a fixed upright headboard, legs are straightened, and feet are at right angles to legs with toes pointing upwards. The length of the baby is measured from a scale set in the measuring table.
  • Measuring the length of a child lying on a mattress or using cloth tapes is inaccurate and not recommended.
  • Height is measured by asking the child to stand upright with heels, buttocks, shoulder blades, and back of the head in contact with a vertical surface such as a wall, height measuring rod, or a stadiometer. The child should look directly forward, and the headpiece is kept firmly over the head to compress the hair.

 

The growth and development of a child between the age of 18 - 24 months can be classified as,

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children typically attain half of their adult height by 20-24 months, a critical milestone in early childhood growth and development.

questions.text: A neonate is found to have increased irritability, poor feeding, and 2 episodes of seizures. Lumbar puncture was done and the findings were suggestive of meningitis. What is the most likely causative organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Streptococcus agalactiae

 

  • Neonatal meningitis is suspected in the given clinical scenario. The most likely causative organism is Streptococcus agalactiae, which is part of group B streptococci.
  • Neonatal meningitis can either have an early or a late start. Late-onset meningitis affects premature infants and is typically caused by coagulase-negative staphylococci (primarily S. epidermidis), as well as S. aureus, E. coli, and Klebsiella species. Early-onset meningitis affects newborns within the first 72 hours of life.
  • Group B streptococci are the most common cause of both meningitis and neonatal sepsis, followed by E. coli. However, E. coli is the most common cause of early-onset sepsis and meningitis among very low birth weight infants (less than 1500 g).

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. Neisseria meningitidis: Asymptomatic meningococcal infections are common. If invasive disease occurs, the clinical spectrum ranges from meningococcal meningitis (which accounts for the majority of cases) to bacteremia without sepsis, meningococcal septicemia with or without meningitis, pneumonia, chronic meningococcemia, and occult bacteremia.

 

Option D. Listeria monocytogenes: Meningitis caused by Listeria monocytogenes is relatively rare but clinically significant. Infants acquire infection in utero or by inoculation through an infected birth canal. Neonatal listeriosis can be,

 

  • Early-onset neonatal disease, which occurs in infants less than 5 days old, usually within 1-2 days of birth. Predominantly septicemic form.
  • Late-onset neonatal disease, which occurs in infants >5 days old. Predominantly meningitic form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Group B Streptococcus (Streptococcus agalactiae) is the most common cause of neonatal meningitis and sepsis, and early recognition and treatment are critical for reducing morbidity and mortality.

choices.text: Direct observation with a structured checklist
In-depth interview with the healthcare provider

questions.text: A newly established hospital aims to maintain the highest standards of care and ensure patient safety by standardizing injection practices among health workers. They seek a reliable method for real-time assessment of these practices. Which of the following would be the most appropriate method to monitor the injection practices of health workers? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Direct observation with a structured checklist

 

  • The most effective approach for assessing the injection practices of healthcare workers is through direct observation using a structured checklist.
  • This method allows for real-time, accurate assessment of adherence to aseptic techniques and best practices.
  • A structured checklist ensures all critical steps are monitored and recorded systematically.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Closed circuit camera surveillance: While it may offer some insights, it lacks the detail and real-time assessment provided by direct observation.

 

Option C. In-depth interview with the patient: Patients may not have the expertise to accurately comment on the technical aspects of injection practices.

 

Option D. In-depth interview with the healthcare provider: This relies on self-reporting, which may be biased and not always accurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most effective approach for assessing the injection practices of healthcare workers is through direct observation using a structured checklist.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy was brought to the outpatient clinic with intentional tremors, and poor scholastic performance. His sister has similar complaints. On examination, hepatomegaly is seen. The eye finding is shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wilson’s disease

 

The most probable diagnosis for this patient, based on the clinical presentation and the image showing icterus in the eyes, is Wilson's disease. Wilson's disease is an autosomal-recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which leads to abnormal copper metabolism. This results in copper accumulation in various tissues, including the liver, brain, cornea, and kidneys.

 

The presence of intentional tremors, poor scholastic performance, and hepatomegaly are consistent with Wilson's disease. The eye finding likely represents a Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring, a characteristic feature of Wilson's disease. The KF ring is a brownish or golden ring around the cornea, which is caused by copper deposition in the Descemet's membrane of the cornea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Huntington's chorea: Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide (CAG) repeat disorder with an autosomal dominant inheritance. It is characterized by involuntary movements (chorea), cognitive decline, and psychiatric disturbances. Unlike Wilson's disease, Huntington's chorea does not typically present with hepatomegaly or KF rings.

 

Option C. Glutaric aciduria: Glutaric aciduria is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder that usually presents in the first 6 months of life. Clinical features include hypotonia, jitteriness, and progressive hyperkinetic movements (dystonia, choreoathetosis). This disorder does not present with the eye findings seen in the image or the liver involvement typical of Wilson's disease.

 

Option D. Hepatitis A: Hepatitis A is a viral infection transmitted primarily through the fecal-oral route. It typically presents with symptoms such as jaundice, nausea, vomiting, anorexia, and mild fever. However, it does not cause the neurological symptoms, intentional tremors, or KF rings seen in Wilson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wilson's disease is characterized by the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings, hepatomegaly, neurological symptoms (such as intentional tremors), and is diagnosed with decreased serum ceruloplasmin, increased 24-hour urinary copper excretion, and the presence of KF rings.

questions.text:
How would you manage a child with status epilepticus? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Airway and breathing
  2. IV Lorazepam
  3. Midazolam, Propofol, Thiopentone
  4. IV Fosphenytoin
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 4, 3

 

Status epilepticus is defined as continuous or recurrent seizure activity lasting for more than 5 minutes without regaining consciousness.

 

Status epilepticus is a neurological emergency defined as continuous or recurrent seizure activity lasting for more than 5 minutes without regaining consciousness between episodes. Prompt and systematic management is essential to prevent long-term neurological damage or death.

 

Management Sequence:

 

1. Airway and Breathing: The first priority is to ensure that the airway is open and that the child is breathing adequately. This may involve positioning the child, providing oxygen, and, if necessary, securing the airway with advanced airway management techniques.

 

2. IV Lorazepam: Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, are the first-line treatment for status epilepticus due to their rapid onset of action and effectiveness in terminating seizures. Lorazepam is typically administered intravenously.

 

4. IV Fosphenytoin: If seizures continue after the administration of a benzodiazepine, IV fosphenytoin (or phenytoin) is used as a second-line agent. It helps to stabilize neuronal membranes and prevent further seizure activity.

 

3. Midazolam, Propofol, Thiopentone: These agents are used if seizures persist despite initial treatments. Midazolam can be administered intramuscularly or intravenously, while propofol and thiopentone are typically reserved for refractory status epilepticus and may require the child to be in an intensive care setting due to the need for mechanical ventilation and close monitoring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of status epilepticus in children should follow a systematic approach: securing the airway and ensuring breathing, administering a benzodiazepine, followed by fosphenytoin if seizures persist, and considering more potent agents like midazolam, propofol, or thiopentone if the status epilepticus is refractory to initial treatments.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child arrived with a history of fever, reddened and congested conjunctiva, along with skin exhibiting redness and peeling, as depicted in the provided images. A 2D echocardiogram revealed the presence of a coronary aneurysm. What constitutes the initial course of treatment for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IVIG

 

The clinical presentation of fever, congested conjunctiva, strawberry tongue, and red skin peeling, along with the echocardiogram finding of a coronary aneurysm, is highly suggestive of Kawasaki disease. Kawasaki disease is a systemic vasculitis that primarily affects children and can lead to coronary artery aneurysms if not treated promptly.

 

Initial Treatment: The mainstay of treatment for Kawasaki disease is the administration of Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG). IVIG is given to reduce the risk of coronary artery aneurysms, which is the most serious complication of Kawasaki disease. The standard dose is 2 g/kg administered as a single infusion, usually within the first 10 days of illness.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Aspirin: Aspirin is also used in the management of Kawasaki disease, typically in conjunction with IVIG. However, IVIG is the first-line treatment to reduce inflammation and prevent coronary complications.

 

Option C. Clopidogrel: Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet agent, but it is not part of the initial treatment for Kawasaki disease.

 

Option D. LMWH: Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) is an anticoagulant, but it is not used as the primary treatment for Kawasaki disease.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In Kawasaki disease, the initial course of treatment involves the administration of IVIG to reduce the risk of coronary artery aneurysms and other complications.

choices.text: It is a single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) virus.
The virus is icosahedral in shape.
Conjunctivitis is typically caused by type 17 D adenovirus.
Haemorrhagic cystitis is caused by serotype 40 & 41.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a fever and a sore throat. Upon examination, he is found to have red, swollen eyes and small blisters on his upper respiratory tract. Laboratory tests confirm an infection with a DNA virus that is non-enveloped. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the virus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The virus is icosahedral in shape.

 

Option B:

 

Adenoviruses are double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) viruses with an icosahedral capsid. They are known to cause a variety of diseases, including conjunctivitis, respiratory illnesses, and gastroenteritis. While adenovirus type 17 can cause respiratory illness, it is not the only type associated with conjunctivitis. Adenovirus types 11 and 21 are associated with hemorrhagic cystitis, and types 40 and 41 are known to cause gastroenteritis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Adenoviruses are not ssDNA viruses; they contain double-stranded DNA.

 

Option C. Type 17 adenovirus can cause respiratory illness, but it is not the only type associated with conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Serotypes 11 and 21 are more commonly associated with hemorrhagic cystitis. Adenovirus types 40 and 41 are typically linked to gastroenteritis (especially in children)

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1/e p449-50,2/e p467-468

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are independently false statements.
The assertion is independently a true statement, but the reason is independently a false statement.
Both assertion and reason are independently true statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.
Both assertion and reason are independently true statements, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion.

questions.text:
Choose the most appropriate answer: (INICET NOV 2022)

 

Assertion: In phenylketonuria, the urine has a mousy odor.

 

Reason: The serum levels of tyrosine, dopamine, and norepinephrine are decreased in phenylketonuria.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both assertion and reason are independently true statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.

 

  • Assertion: The statement that "In phenylketonuria, the urine has a mousy odor" is true. The mousy or musty odor of the urine in phenylketonuria (PKU) is due to the accumulation of phenylacetate, one of the metabolites of phenylalanine.
  • Reason: The statement that "The serum levels of tyrosine, dopamine, and norepinephrine are decreased in phenylketonuria" is also true. Phenylketonuria is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, which converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. Consequently, low levels of tyrosine lead to reduced synthesis of catecholamines such as dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine.

 

However, the reason provided is not the correct explanation for the assertion. The mousy odor in PKU is directly related to the accumulation of phenylacetate, not to the decreased levels of tyrosine or catecholamines.

 

Detailed Mechanism:

 

  • Phenylketonuria (PKU): PKU is an inborn error of metabolism caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase or, less commonly, a defect in enzymes responsible for producing tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4). This defect results in impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine, leading to the accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites, such as phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate, which are excreted in the urine.
  • Tyrosine and Catecholamine Synthesis: Tyrosine is a precursor for the synthesis of catecholamines, including dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine. In PKU, the deficiency of tyrosine leads to reduced synthesis of these neurotransmitters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In phenylketonuria, the mousy odor of urine is due to the accumulation of phenylacetate, while decreased levels of tyrosine and catecholamines are a result of the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. However, the two phenomena are not causally related.

questions.text: In a village population, patients having diabetes and hypertension are enumerated. Then their family members are screening for diabetes and hypertension. This is a type of: [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Selective screening

 

  • This is an example of selective screening, which is a type of screening applied to high-risk groups - individuals who have a higher chance of developing a particular disease. 
  • In this case, family members of patients with diabetes and hypertension are being screened because they are at higher risk of developing these conditions due to genetic predisposition and shared environmental factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mass screening: This is incorrect because mass screening refers to screening applied to a large population without considering risk factors. Mass screening is conducted on a "large number of people" without specific risk targeting, like "chest x-ray in elderly for lung cancer." The given scenario is specifically targeting family members of already diagnosed patients, not the entire population.

 

Option C. Multiphasic screening: This is incorrect because multiphasic screening involves applying more than two tests to a large number of people. Multiphasic screening as where "more than 2 tests are used or applied in large number of people like annual health checkup." In the given scenario, we're only screening for two specific conditions (diabetes and hypertension) in a targeted group, not conducting multiple tests on a large population.

 

Option D. Anonymous screening: This is incorrect because refers to a type of medical testing where individuals are tested for a condition (such as HIV) without providing any personal identifying information. 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A child with thalassemia is undergoing multiple blood transfusions. What is the best method to detect iron overload? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Liver iron concentration

 

  • Children with thalassemia who undergo multiple blood transfusions are at risk of iron overload, which can cause significant damage to organs such as the liver, heart, and endocrine glands.
  • Monitoring liver iron concentration is the best method to assess iron overload in such children, as it is an indicator of total body iron stores.
  • Liver iron concentration can be measured invasively using a liver biopsy or non-invasively using T2 MRI of the liver. The latter is preferred due to its non-invasiveness.
  • Treatment for iron overload in thalassemia patients typically involves the use of chelation therapy, which helps to remove excess iron from the body. Deferoxamine is typically given through intravenous or subcutaneous infusion, while deferasirox and deferiprone can be given orally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI T2 myocardium: Quantitative iron overload in the heart is determined using a T2 MRI of the myocardium. However, it can be done sooner if there are symptoms of severe iron overload. It is often performed in children older than 10 years. If the patient's transfusion and chelation histories are unknown, it can still be done.

 

Option C. Serum ferritin: Although serum ferritin is elevated, other inflammatory disorders also cause it to be elevated, making it a less sensitive marker.

 

Option D. NTBI (Non-transferrin-bound iron): Iron in plasma is typically bound to cccc. However, when there is an excess of iron, it is unable to bind to transferrin, which results in the formation of non-transferrin-bound iron. (NTBI). It may serve as a marker for iron excess, however albumin, citrate, and uric acid in the plasma all have an impact. As a result, it cannot be utilized as a tool to quantify iron overload and serve as a guide for designing chelation therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best method to detect iron overload in a patient receiving repeated blood transfusions is Liver iron concentration.

choices.text: Biliary atresia is the most common cause of neonatal cholestasis
Kasai procedure should be done within 90 days
HIDA scan is used for diagnosis
Can be differentiated from other differential diagnoses by biopsy

questions.text: All of the following are true about neonatal cholestasis, except? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kasai procedure should be done within 90 days

 

Neonatal cholestasis is defined as conjugated hyperbilirubinemia that occurs in the newborn period, typically presenting with jaundice, pale stools, and dark urine. Biliary atresia is indeed the most common cause of surgically correctable neonatal cholestasis, accounting for approximately 25-30% of cases.

 

The statement about the Kasai procedure (portoenterostomy) is incorrect. The Kasai procedure should be performed within 60 days of life, not 90 days. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biliary atresia is the most common cause of neonatal cholestasis: This statement is true. Biliary atresia is the most common identifiable cause of neonatal cholestasis, accounting for approximately 25-30% of cases. It is characterized by progressive obliteration of extrahepatic bile ducts.

 

Option C. HIDA scan is used for diagnosis: This statement is true. Hepatobiliary scintigraphy using technetium-99m-labeled iminodiacetic acid derivatives (HIDA scan) is a valuable diagnostic tool for neonatal cholestasis. It helps distinguish biliary atresia from other causes by demonstrating the absence of radiotracer excretion into the intestine in biliary atresia.

 

Option D. Can be differentiated from other differential diagnoses by biopsy: This statement is true. Liver biopsy remains a cornerstone in the diagnostic evaluation of neonatal cholestasis. Histopathological findings such as bile duct proliferation, portal tract fibrosis, and giant cell transformation can help differentiate biliary atresia from other causes of neonatal cholestasis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Kasai procedure (portoenterostomy) for biliary atresia should be performed within 60 days of life, not 90 days, as earlier intervention is associated with better outcomes.

questions.text:
Regarding urinary tract infection (UTI) in children, which of the following is true? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Most common cause of UTI is Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  2. Bowel, bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrence.
  3. Cotrimoxazole is not given.
  4. Micturating cysto-urethrogram (MCU) is done in children with recurrence of UTI.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4

 

It is true that bowel and bladder dysfunction increase the incidence of recurrence of UTI in children, and that children who experience a recurrence of UTI undergo a micturating cystourethrogram (MCU). 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that bowel and bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrent UTIs in children, and that MCU is performed in cases of recurrent UTI to assess for anatomical and functional abnormalities.

questions.text: Handedness is seen at the age of? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3 years

 

At age of 3 years, handedness is seen. The child may become frustrated if attempts are made in changing the hand preference.

 

Other milestones reached at 3 years-

 

  • Rides tricycle
  • Alternate feet going upstairs
  • Builds a tower of 9 blocks
  • Copies a circle
  • Knows full name and gender

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 year: Standing without support comes by 1 year

 

Option B. 2 years: A child has vocab of 100 words by 2 years

 

Option D. 4 years: A child can tell poem & stories by 4 years

 

Educational Objective:

 

At the age of 3 years, handedness is seen.

questions.text: A 2 yr old child presented with fever, thrombocytopenia, hematuria. The mother tells you that the baby also suffered from diarrhea a few days back. Which is the most common organism for likely cause? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E. Coli 0157:H7

 

The clinical presentation describes classic features of Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS), characterized by the triad of:

 

  • Hemolytic anemia 
  • Thrombocytopenia  
  • Acute kidney injury 

 

The most common causative organism for typical or diarrhea-associated HUS is Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC), particularly serotype O157:H7. This toxin damages endothelial cells, leading to platelet activation, microthrombi formation, and end-organ damage, particularly affecting the kidneys.

 

HUS is one of the most common causes of acute kidney injury in young children. Management focuses on supportive care, including careful fluid management, treatment of hypertension, and renal replacement therapy if needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salmonella: While Salmonella can cause gastroenteritis and bacteremia, it is not typically associated with HUS. Salmonella infections commonly present with fever, diarrhea, and abdominal pain but do not typically progress to the triad of HUS.

 

Option C. Shigella: Although Shigella dysenteriae type 1 can produce Shiga toxin and cause HUS, it is much less common than E. coli O157:H7 as a cause of HUS, particularly in developed countries.

 

Option D. Yersinia: Yersinia enterocolitica can cause gastroenteritis but is not a common cause of HUS. It typically causes fever, diarrhea, and right lower quadrant pain that can mimic appendicitis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The clinical presentation of Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) following diarrheal illness and identify E. coli O157:H7 as the most common causative organism.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child with a body weight of 15kg and height of 100cm is admitted with renal failure. His blood urea was 100 mg/dL and serum creatinine was 1 mg/dL. What is the closest calculated eGFR in the patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 40 ml/min/1.73 m2 BSA

 

Step-by-Step Calculation

 

Step 1: Identify the appropriate k value

For a 4-year-old child: k = 0.413

 

Step 2: Apply the formula

eGFR = k × Height / Serum Creatinine

 

Step 3: Substitute values

eGFR = 0.413 × 100 / 1

 

Step 4: Calculate

eGFR = 41.3 / 1 = 41.3 ml/min/1.73 m²

 

Step 5: Round to nearest option

41.3 ≈ 40 ml/min/1.73 m² BSA
 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eGFR) in pediatric patients can be calculated using the Schwartz formula, which is widely used in clinical practice. The formula takes into account the patient's height and serum creatinine levels, along with a constant value that is adjusted for age and sex.

 

The modified Schwartz formula is most commonly used for this purpose. It is given as:

 

 

 

For children aged 1 to 16 years, the constant k is typically 0.413

 

Given the child's height of 100 cm and serum creatinine of 1 mg/dL:

 

 

 

The closest value provided in the options is 40 ml/min/1.73 m² BSA, which is therefore the correct answer

 

Understand and apply the Schwartz formula for estimating eGFR in pediatric patients based on height and serum creatinine levels.

questions.text: Which can be used as an alternative to breast milk in low birth weight (LBW) child? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Human donor milk

 

  • Human donor milk is the alternative to breast milk in low birth weight infants
  • Low birth weight refers to birth weight less than 2500 grams due to preterm birth or intrauterine growth restriction or both
  • All low birth weight babies should be fed only by breast milk, regardless of the feeding method
  • Expressed breast milk or human donor milk should be given to infants fed by paladai or gastric tube

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Preterm formula & Option C. Term formula: Formula feeds, including term formula feed for infants weighing ≥1500 g at birth and preterm formula feed for very low birth weight infants, can be given when there is a contraindication to breastfeeding or if the mother is sick or human donor milk is not available or toned milk is not available.

 

Option A. Cow milk: Cow milk is not given because it is rich in casein. Casein causes constipation, colicky pain and cow milk protein allergy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human donor milk is the alternative to breast milk in low birth weight infants

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of some dehydration in a 5-year-old child?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lethargy

 

Lethargy is a sign of severe dehydration, not some dehydration. In the context of dehydration, it is important to differentiate between signs that indicate mild to moderate (some) dehydration and those that suggest severe dehydration. Lethargy indicates a more serious state of fluid loss that affects the child's overall responsiveness and energy levels, which is not characteristic of mild or moderate dehydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delayed skin pinch: This sign can occur in both some and severe dehydration. When the skin, typically on the abdomen or arm, is pinched and it returns to its original position slowly, it indicates decreased skin turgor, a common sign of dehydration.

 

Option B. Sunken eyeballs: Sunken eyes can be a symptom of both some and severe dehydration. It is a visible sign that reflects reduced fluid in the body, causing the eyes to appear sunken.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because one of the choices (lethargy) is not a sign of some dehydration but rather severe dehydration.

 

Educational Objective:


Lethargy is a sign of severe dehydration, whereas delayed skin pinch and sunken eyeballs can be signs of both some and severe dehydration in a 5-year-old child.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structure is damaged in respiratory distress syndrome? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

The structure marked as 2 represents Type II pneumocytes, which are crucial in the pathophysiology of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).

 

Key Points:

 

  • Type I pneumocytes (Marked as 1): These cells are large and flattened, making up the majority of the alveolar surface area. They form the thin barrier necessary for efficient gas exchange.
  • Type II pneumocytes (Marked as 2): These cells are rounded and responsible for producing surfactant, a substance composed of phospholipids and proteins that reduces surface tension within the alveoli. Surfactant is essential for preventing alveolar collapse (atelectasis) during exhalation. In respiratory distress syndrome, especially in premature infants, the deficiency or dysfunction of these Type II cells leads to insufficient surfactant production, causing the alveoli to collapse and resulting in severe breathing difficulties.
  • Endothelial cells of capillaries (Marked as 3): These cells line the blood vessels within the lungs and are involved in the exchange of gases between the blood and alveoli. They are not primarily involved in the pathogenesis of RDS.
  • Red Blood Cells (Marked as 4): These are the cells responsible for carrying oxygen from the lungs to the rest of the body and returning carbon dioxide to the lungs for exhalation. While essential for overall respiratory function, they are not the site of damage in RDS.

 

Clinical Relevance:

 

  • Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS): Commonly seen in premature infants, RDS is primarily caused by a deficiency of surfactant due to immature Type II pneumocytes. The lack of surfactant leads to increased surface tension, alveolar collapse, and severe respiratory distress. This condition is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in preterm infants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type II pneumocytes are crucial for surfactant production and alveolar stability, and their dysfunction or immaturity is the primary cause of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in neonates.

questions.text:
Which among the following is false about breast milk jaundice: (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Breast feeding should be completely stopped
  2. Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  3. Phototherapy is required to treat most cases
  4. Bilirubin levels are usually more than 10 mg/dL at 3-4 weeks
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a and c

 

Breast milk jaundice is a type of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that occurs in breastfed infants typically beginning after the first week of life and can persist for several weeks. It is caused by certain components in breast milk (3-alpha-20-beta-diol and beta-glucuronidase) that inhibit the conjugation and excretion of bilirubin.

 

a. "Breast feeding should be completely stopped" - This is FALSE. Current guidelines do not recommend stopping breastfeeding for breast milk jaundice. Despite the jaundice being associated with breast milk, the benefits of breastfeeding outweigh the risks of the typically benign and self-limiting jaundice.

 

c. "Phototherapy is required to treat most cases" - This is also FALSE. Most cases of breast milk jaundice are mild and resolve spontaneously without phototherapy. Phototherapy is only required in cases where bilirubin levels reach potentially concerning levels.

 

Correct Statements:

 

b. "Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia" - This statement is TRUE. Breast milk jaundice is characterized by unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia because the components in breast milk affect the conjugation and excretion of bilirubin in the liver.

 

d. "Bilirubin levels are usually more than 10 mg/dL at 3-4 weeks" - This statement is TRUE. Breast milk jaundice typically presents with bilirubin levels that can persist above 10 mg/dL during the first 3-4 weeks of life, unlike physiological jaundice which resolves earlier.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Breast milk jaundice does not require stopping breastfeeding and most cases do not require phototherapy, despite causing unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia with levels that may exceed 10 mg/dL at 3-4 weeks of age.

questions.text: Which of the following congenital heart disease has equal saturation in all the chambers of the heart? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation

 

  • TAPVC is a congenital heart defect where oxygenated blood from the pulmonary veins does not reach the left atrium but instead reaches the right atrium, which contains deoxygenated blood.
  • The pulmonary veins drain into the superior vena cava or the inferior vena cava, or both, causing a total mixing lesion. This mixing lesion leads to the oxygenated blood passing to the right ventricle and pulmonary artery, and to the left atrium through the atrial septal defect or the patent foramen ovale, and then to the left ventricle.
  • The left atrium receives blood only from this shunt and not from the pulmonary veins, as all of them are draining to the right atrium.
  • This shunt causes equal saturation of oxygenated blood in all four chambers of the heart since the blood from the right atrium reaches all other chambers.  TAPVC can present with cyanosis, respiratory distress, tachypnea, tachycardia, and poor feeding in neonates.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by echocardiography, which shows the abnormal venous return of the pulmonary veins.
  • Treatment requires surgical repair to establish normal pulmonary venous return and improve oxygen saturation. The surgery should be performed as soon as possible to prevent irreversible pulmonary hypertension and cardiac failure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetralogy of Fallot: Tetralogy of fallot will not have some saturation in all chambers. Remember the x ray finding is “ boot shape heart “

 

Option C. Tricuspid atresia: Tricuspid atresia will have decrease blood flow going from right atrium to right ventricle. So there will be difference in saturation in chambers.

 

Option D. Transposition of great arteries: In this condition the pulmonary artery is attached to the left ventricle & aorta is attached to the right ventricle which leads to parallel circulation. There will be saturation difference.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Circulation (TAPVC), there is equal oxygen saturation in all chambers of the heart due to the complete mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood in the right atrium.

questions.text: A young man is brought to the hospital with high-grade fever and altered consciousness. On examination, the patient had neck rigidity and pain when bending the neck. A lumbar puncture was performed and it showed a WBC count of 1500 cells/ L, majority being neutrophils, elevated pressure with protein of 120 mg/dL, and a CSF glucose level of 70 mg dL & blood glucose level - 300 mg dL). How will you manage the index case? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vancomycin + ceftriaxone

 

The clinical scenario and the laboratory results provided strongly suggest a diagnosis of bacterial meningitis.
