The CSF analysis shows significant findings including a high WBC count predominantly composed of neutrophils, elevated protein, and a relatively low CSF glucose level considering the elevated blood glucose. The CSF glucose level, when compared to the blood glucose, gives a ratio that is suggestive of bacterial meningitis (a ratio of 0.4 or less is highly indicative).

 

Meningitis can present with symptoms such as high-grade fever, altered consciousness, neck rigidity, and positive meningeal signs like Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs. The diagnosis is confirmed by CSF analysis, which typically shows:

 

  • Neutrophilic pleocytosis
  • Increased protein levels
  • Decreased glucose concentrations
  • Presence of microorganisms on Gram stain and culture

 

The initial treatment of bacterial meningitis should include broad-spectrum antibiotics that cover the most common pathogens. A combination of a third-generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone and vancomycin is recommended to cover for Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitidis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Piperacillin + tazobactam: Piperacillin + tazobactam is used in certain situations such as hospital-acquired infections or when there is no response to ceftriaxone. However, it is not the first-line treatment for community-acquired bacterial meningitis.

 

Option B. Amphotericin + flucytosine: Amphotericin + flucytosine are antifungal agents used to treat fungal meningitis, not bacterial meningitis. Fungal meningitis presents differently and typically in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Antitubercular therapy: Antitubercular therapy is considered when the CSF profile shows low glucose, high protein, and lymphocytic predominance, which is typical for tuberculous meningitis. The provided CSF findings do not match those of tuberculous meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vancomycin combined with a third-generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone is the recommended initial treatment for suspected bacterial meningitis.

questions.text: The following finding can be seen in: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parvovirus B19 infection

 

The 5th disease, also known as erythema infectiosum, is caused by Parvovirus B19. It is a common childhood viral infection characterized by a "slapped-cheek" rash.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Molluscum contagiosum: This is not correct. Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus. It does not cause the 5th disease.

 

Option C. HFMD (Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease): HFMD is caused by enteroviruses, primarily Coxsackievirus A16 and Enterovirus 71. It does not cause the 5th disease.

 

Option D. Kawasaki disease: Kawasaki disease is not caused by Parvovirus B19. It is an inflammatory condition of blood vessels, and its etiology is not related to the virus responsible for the 5th disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the causative agent of the 5th disease (erythema infectiosum) as Parvovirus B19. Understand the clinical manifestations of the 5th disease, including the characteristic "slapped-cheek" rash, and differentiate it from other childhood viral infections such as HFMD and conditions like Kawasaki disease and molluscum contagiosum.

choices.text: Age 6 months – 5 years
Simple febrile seizure lasts for <15 minutes
No need for long term antiepileptics

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about febrile seizure?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 54% recurrence

 

Febrile seizures are convulsions brought on by a fever in infants or small children. They are relatively common and typically occur between the ages of 6 months and 5 years. The main features of febrile seizures include:

 

  • Age 6 months – 5 years: This is the typical age range for febrile seizures, making this statement true.
  • Simple febrile seizure lasts for <15 minutes: Simple febrile seizures are brief, usually lasting less than 15 minutes. This statement is also true.
  • No need for long term antiepileptic: In the case of simple febrile seizures, long-term antiepileptic treatment is generally not necessary. This statement is true as well.

 

The statement "54% recurrence" is not true. The recurrence rate for febrile seizures is significantly lower. While there is a risk of recurrence, it is not as high as 54%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Febrile seizures typically occur between the ages of 6 months and 5 years, last less than 15 minutes, and do not require long-term antiepileptic treatment. The recurrence rate is much lower than 54%.

questions.text: A child came to OPD with fever for 6 days with strawberry tongue, conjunctival congestion, and peeling of skin. What should be the ideal treatment? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IVIG

 

  • The constellation of symptoms described (fever, strawberry tongue, conjunctival congestion, and peeling skin) is suggestive of Kawasaki disease. IVIG is a key component of the treatment for Kawasaki disease to reduce the risk of coronary artery abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aspirin: This is also a crucial part of the treatment for Kawasaki disease. Aspirin is used in Kawasaki disease to reduce inflammation and the risk of blood clot formation. However, it is often used in conjunction with IVIG.

 

Option C. Plenty of fluids: While maintaining hydration is important, fluid administration alone is not the primary treatment for Kawasaki disease. The use of IVIG and aspirin is more specific to address the underlying inflammatory process.

 

Option D. Cephalosporins: Cephalosporins are antibiotics and are not the appropriate treatment for Kawasaki disease, which is not caused by a bacterial infection.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Fever + 4 out of 5 below = Classic Kawasaki

questions.text: Causes of non-immune hydrops fetalis are all except: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ABO incompatibility

 

  • ABO incompatibility is an immune-mediated cause of hemolytic disease of the newborn, but it is not typically associated with non-immune hydrops fetalis. Non-immune hydrops is often caused by factors other than immune reactions, such as congenital heart defects, infections, or chromosomal anomalies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congestive cardiac failure: Congestive cardiac failure can contribute to non-immune hydrops fetalis. Conditions affecting the fetal heart can lead to fluid accumulation, resulting in hydrops.

 

Option C. Parvovirus infection: Parvovirus infection is a known cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis. Parvovirus can affect the developing fetus and lead to severe anemia, causing fluid accumulation.

 

Option D. Chromosomal anomalies: Chromosomal anomalies, such as Turner syndrome or trisomy 21, are associated with non-immune hydrops fetalis. Abnormalities in fetal development, including those affecting multiple organ systems, can lead to fluid accumulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the various causes of non-immune hydrops fetalis. Understand that conditions such as congestive cardiac failure, infections (e.g., parvovirus), and chromosomal anomalies can contribute to the development of hydrops in the absence of immune-mediated factors. Be aware that ABO incompatibility is not a typical cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis.

questions.text: A baby is brought to OPD for 10-week DPT vaccination appointment. He previously experienced a fever exceeding 40°C and had an inconsolable cry at 6 weeks old after receiving a vaccination. What would be the recommended course of action moving forward? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give DT vaccine

 

The child experienced a hypotonic-hyporesponsive episode or severe reaction (fever >40°C and persistent inconsolable crying) after the previous DPT dose. These are precautionary (not absolute contraindications) for pertussis-containing vaccines like DPT, but they warrant switching to a less reactogenic formulation.

 

DT (Diphtheria + Tetanus) vaccine is recommended in such cases, as it omits the pertussis component, which is most often responsible for such adverse events.

 

This allows continuation of diphtheria and tetanus protection while avoiding further adverse events from the pertussis component.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Avoid DPT vaccination: Incorrect. DPT is contraindicated, but not all vaccinations should be avoided. The child should still receive protection against diphtheria and tetanus.

 

Option C. Give DPT vaccine: Incorrect. Given the prior adverse reaction, repeating DPT may risk more serious reactions. It’s prudent to avoid the pertussis component.

 

Option D. Defer by 4 weeks: Incorrect. There's no benefit in deferring the dose. The issue is not timing but the component that caused the reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe reactions (such as high fever >40.5°C, persistent inconsolable crying >3 hours, or hypotonic-hyporesponsive episodes) after a previous DPT dose are indications to withhold the pertussis component in future doses. The child should receive the DT vaccine instead.

questions.text: Calculate the Downe score of a newborn who has cyanosis which improves on giving oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, air entry markedly decreased, RR 40 per minute?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6

 

The Downe score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in newborns. It consists of five components: cyanosis, retractions, grunting, air entry, and respiratory rate (RR). Each component is scored from 0 to 2, with a total possible score of 10. Here's the breakdown for the given case:

 

 

Summing up the scores:


1 (cyanosis) + 1 (retractions) + 2 (grunting) + 2 (air entry) + 0 (RR) = 6

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Downe score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in newborns. A score of 6 in this case indicates moderate respiratory distress, characterized by cyanosis that improves with oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, markedly decreased air entry, and a normal respiratory rate.

questions.text: What is the rate of increment of head circumference in the first three months of life?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 cm per month

 

During the first three months of life, the head circumference of a baby increases by approximately 2 cm per month. This rapid growth is due to the significant brain development occurring during this period. After the first three months, the growth rate slows down. From three to six months of age, the head circumference increases by about 1 cm per month, and from six months to one year, it increases by about 0.5 cm per month.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The head circumference of a baby increases by approximately 2 cm per month during the first three months of life.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Downs syndrome?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Caudal regression syndrome

 

  • Caudal regression syndrome is not typically associated with Down syndrome. Caudal regression syndrome is a congenital disorder characterized by abnormal development of the lower spine (caudal region). It is a separate condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism is a known association with Down syndrome. 

 

Option B. Hearing loss: Hearing loss is commonly observed in individuals with Down syndrome. Ear infections and structural abnormalities may contribute to this condition.

 

Option C. Short stature: Short stature is a characteristic feature of Down syndrome. Individuals with Down syndrome often have a shorter stature compared to the general population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the common clinical features and associated conditions of Down syndrome. Understand that hypothyroidism, hearing loss, and short stature are commonly observed in individuals with Down syndrome. Be aware of the distinct features of other congenital conditions, such as caudal regression syndrome, that are not typically associated with Down syndrome.

choices.text: No Complete absence of edema by day 20
Weight gain less than 5 gm/kg/day for 3 consecutive days

questions.text: Treatment non-responsive Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) includes all except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) No complete absence of edema by day 20

 

Non-responsive SAM refers to cases where the child does not show expected improvement despite standard treatment protocols. The standard criteria for non-responsive SAM include:

 

In a responsive case of SAM with edema, the edema should begin to reduce by day 4 and should completely resolve by day 10 (not day 20 as stated in option C). Therefore, stating that "no complete absence of edema by day 20" as a criterion for non-responsive SAM is incorrect, as edema should be gone well before day 20 even in responsive cases.

 

The correct timeline for edema resolution is:

 

  • Beginning of reduction by day 4
  • Complete resolution by day 10

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Appetite not increased by day 4: This is a valid criterion for non-responsive SAM. Typically, appetite should begin to improve by day 4 of treatment. If this doesn't occur, it indicates a non-responsive case that may require additional interventions.

 

Option B. No edema reduction by day 4: This is a valid criterion for non-responsive SAM. In responsive cases of SAM with edema, reduction should begin by day 4.

 

Option D. Weight gain less than 5 gm/kg/day for 3 consecutive days: This is also a valid criterion for non-responsive SAM. The expected weight gain in responsive SAM treatment is at least 5 gm/kg/day. Failure to achieve this indicates poor response to treatment.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

SAM with edema, complete resolution of edema should occur by day 10 of treatment, not day 20, and identify the correct criteria for non-responsive SAM including lack of appetite improvement by day 4, no edema reduction by day 4, and insufficient weight gain.

questions.text: The hormone that does not play a role in the growth of the fetus is: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Growth hormone.

 

Fetal growth is a complex process regulated by various hormones, but growth hormone does not play a significant role in this process during fetal life. The primary hormones involved in fetal growth include insulin, thyroxine, and glucocorticoids.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Insulin: Insulin is crucial for fetal growth, especially during the third trimester. It plays a key role in promoting the storage of nutrients and the growth of fetal tissues, particularly adipose tissue and muscle.
  • Thyroxine: Fetal production of thyroxine begins around the 12th week of gestation. Thyroxine is vital for the development of the central nervous system and overall growth and differentiation of tissues.
  • Glucocorticoids: Glucocorticoids are essential towards the end of gestation, particularly for the maturation of organs such as the lungs, liver, and gastrointestinal tract. They help prepare the fetus for life outside the womb by stimulating the production of surfactant in the lungs and facilitating the maturation of other critical systems.
  • Growth Hormone: Unlike in postnatal life, where growth hormone is a key regulator of growth, its role in fetal growth is minimal. Fetal growth is largely driven by insulin and other growth factors rather than growth hormone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insulin and Option C. Thyroxine: Both are crucial for fetal growth, regulating tissue growth and differentiation, especially in the later stages of pregnancy.

 

Option D. Glucocorticoids: These hormones are essential for the maturation of fetal organs before birth, particularly in the liver, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth hormone does not play a significant role in fetal growth, which is primarily regulated by insulin, thyroxine, and glucocorticoids.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator of some dehydration in SAM? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urine output, Thirst & oral mucosa

 

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) in children can present as either Kwashiorkor or Marasmus. These conditions cause the child to appear very thin and emaciated, making it challenging to rely on typical physical signs like skin pinch or sunken eyeballs for dehydration assessment. SAM children, especially those with Marasmus, already have a "baggy pant" appearance and very thin skin, making these signs unreliable.

 

The most reliable indicator of dehydration in SAM children is assessing urine output, thirst and the condition of the oral mucosa:

 

  • ⁠Urine output, thirst: If the child eagerly drinks water, it indicates some dehydration. Refusal to drink or feed may suggest severe dehydration.
  • ⁠Oral mucosa: Checking the dryness of the oral mucosa is a practical and reliable method. In SAM children, if the oral mucosa is dry, it indicates dehydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skin pinch: This option is incorrect because SAM children already have very thin skin, making skin pinch an unreliable indicator.

 

Option B. Sunken eyeballs: This option is incorrect as SAM children naturally have sunken eyeballs due to severe weight loss and malnutrition, making this sign unreliable for detecting dehydration.

 

Option D. Absent tears: this indicator is not the best indicator. It can be seen in some as well as severe dehydration cases. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In SAM children, the best indicators of dehydration are urine output, the dryness of the oral mucosa and the child's thirst.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old child presents with altered sensorium, persistent headache, and photophobia for the past 5 days. On examination, he has signs of meningeal irritation. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals:what is your diagnosis?
Protein: 93 mg/dL


Glucose: 20 mg/dL (serum glucose = 90 mg/dL)


Cell count: Predominantly lymphocytic pleocytosis (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tubercular meningitis

 

  • Tubercular meningitis is often associated with CSF findings of elevated protein, decreased glucose, and lymphocytic pleocytosis. These findings are consistent with the given CSF results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis: The CSF findings of elevated protein, decreased glucose, and an increased number of neutrophil predominance (not lymphocytes) are suggestive of meningitis. However, bacterial meningitis is more commonly associated with a significantly higher white blood cell count (pleocytosis) in the CSF. The given CSF results are not typical for bacterial meningitis.

 

Option B. Viral meningitis: This is a potential consideration. Viral meningitis can present with elevated protein, normal or mildly reduced glucose, and an increased number of lymphocytes in the CSF. It is a common cause of aseptic (non-bacterial) meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: At 6 weeks of life, a child developed a fever after DPT vaccination. And now child is 10 weeks due for vaccination. What should be done next? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Give DPT Vaccination

 

  • Fever following a DPT vaccination does not necessarily contraindicate subsequent doses. The child should receive the next scheduled DPT vaccination unless there are specific contraindications or severe adverse reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Give DT: Giving only DT (Diphtheria and Tetanus) without the pertussis component may not be ideal for overall protection against these diseases. It's important to provide the complete vaccination schedule, including DPT, unless contraindications exist.

 

Option C. Don’t give DPT: This may not be the best course of action. Fever following the initial DPT vaccination is not an absolute contraindication to subsequent doses. The child should continue the vaccination schedule unless there are specific contraindications.

 

Option D. Don’t give any vaccination: This is not the recommended approach. Missing or delaying vaccinations may leave the child susceptible to vaccine-preventable diseases. It's important to adhere to the recommended vaccination schedule whenever possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the approach to managing adverse events following immunization. Recognize that mild reactions, such as fever after a vaccine, do not necessarily contraindicate subsequent doses. Adherence to the recommended vaccination schedule is crucial for providing timely and effective protection against vaccine-preventable diseases

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Neonates who are asymptomatic at birth have a lesser risk of later sequelae.
  2. 20-40% are symptomatic at birth.
  3. In developing countries, the rate of transmission of CMV infection to the infant is more common from primary maternal infection than reactivation.
  4. Diagnosis by urine specimen at 4 weeks of age
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3

 

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a common congenital infection, and understanding the nuances of its transmission, diagnosis, and clinical implications is important.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Congenital CMV Infection:
    • Transmission: Congenital CMV infection can occur from either primary maternal infection (which is when the mother is infected with CMV for the first time during pregnancy) or from reactivation of a prior CMV infection in the mother. The risk of transmission to the fetus is significantly higher in cases of primary maternal infection (around 30%) compared to reactivation (about 1-2%). In developing countries, the prevalence of CMV reactivation is higher, but primary infection remains the more significant source of transmission to the fetus.
    • Asymptomatic vs. Symptomatic: The majority of neonates with congenital CMV are asymptomatic at birth, and these asymptomatic infants have a lower risk of developing long-term sequelae such as sensorineural hearing loss compared to those who are symptomatic at birth.
    • Clinical Presentation: About 10% of neonates with congenital CMV infection are symptomatic at birth. Symptoms can include hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rash, jaundice, chorioretinitis, microcephaly, and thrombocytopenia. These symptoms are associated with a higher risk of long-term complications.
    • Diagnosis: CMV infection can be diagnosed by detecting the virus in urine, saliva, or blood within the first three weeks of life. Diagnosis at four weeks, as mentioned in option 4, is less likely to be reliable because it may represent postnatal infection rather than congenital infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B (1, 2): The percentage of neonates symptomatic at birth is around 10%, not 20-40%.

 

Option C (2, 4): The diagnosis by urine specimen at four weeks is not ideal, and the percentage of symptomatic neonates at birth is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonates who are asymptomatic at birth from congenital CMV infection have a lower risk of long-term sequelae, and transmission is more common from primary maternal infection than from reactivation, especially in developing countries.

questions.text:
An unconscious child is brought to the casualty. What is the correct sequence of the management? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Assess breathing
  2. Assess pulse
  3. Assess response
  4. Start compressions
  5. Bag and mask ventilation
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3-1-2-4-5

 

When managing an unconscious child, especially in a potential cardiac or respiratory arrest scenario, it is crucial to follow the steps of Basic Life Support (BLS) in the correct sequence to ensure the best chance of recovery.

 

 

Sequence Justification:

 

  • The correct sequence is 3-1-2-4-5, which means:
    • 3: First, assess response (to determine unresponsiveness).
    • 1: Then assess breathing (to check for normal breathing).
    • 2: Followed by assessing the pulse (to check for circulation).
    • 4: Start compressions if necessary (if no pulse or poor perfusion).
    • 5: Provide bag and mask ventilation to support breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In BLS, the correct sequence of actions is crucial for effective management. Start by assessing response, followed by breathing and pulse, then initiate compressions and ventilation as needed.

questions.text:
Which of the following increase the risk of recurrence of febrile seizures? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Age < 1 year
  2. Temperature of 38-39°C
  3. Duration of fever < 24 h
  4. Duration of fever > 48 h
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3

 

The risk of recurrent febrile seizures is increased in children who are less than 1 year old, have a fever with a temperature between 38-39°C, and have a fever duration of less than 24 hours. Febrile seizures typically occur in children between the ages of 6 and 60 months and are generalized tonic-clonic seizures that occur in the setting of fever without any underlying intracranial infection or a previous history of unprovoked seizures.

 

Risk Factors:

 

1. Age < 1 year: Younger age increases the likelihood of recurrent febrile seizures.

 

2. Temperature of 38-39°C: Lower fever temperatures (38-39°C) are associated with a higher risk of recurrence.

 

3. Duration of fever < 24 h: A shorter duration of fever before the onset of seizures is associated with an increased risk of recurrence.

 

Other Information:

 

  • Minor risk factors for recurrence include male gender, attending daycare, having complex febrile seizures, a family history of febrile seizures, and lower serum sodium levels at presentation.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Duration of fever > 48 hours: A duration of fever greater than 48 hours is not considered a risk factor for febrile seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The risk of recurrent febrile seizures is increased in children under 1 year of age, with fever temperatures between 38-39°C, and fever lasting less than 24 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following is not caused by parvovirus B19?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Petechial rash

 

Parvovirus B19 is known to cause several conditions, including erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), which presents with a characteristic "slapped cheek" rash in children. It can also affect red blood cells, leading to pure red cell aplasia and aplastic crisis, especially in individuals with underlying hemolytic disorders. In pregnant women, parvovirus B19 infection can cause hydrops fetalis, a serious condition characterized by severe fetal anemia and fluid accumulation. However, petechial rash is not typically associated with parvovirus B19 infection. Petechial rashes are more commonly linked to other viral infections or conditions that cause thrombocytopenia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pure red cell aplasia: Parvovirus B19 can infect erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow, leading to pure red cell aplasia, particularly in individuals with compromised immune systems or underlying hematologic disorders.

 

Option B. Hydrops fetalis: Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can lead to hydrops fetalis due to severe fetal anemia, making this a well-documented complication.

 

Option C. Aplastic crisis: In individuals with chronic hemolytic anemias, such as sickle cell disease, parvovirus B19 infection can precipitate an aplastic crisis by temporarily halting red blood cell production in the bone marrow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 can cause pure red cell aplasia, aplastic crisis, and hydrops fetalis, but it is not associated with petechial rash.

choices.text: Found in monovalent & pentavalent variant
Rotavirus should not be given after 6 months

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding rotavirus vaccine?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rotavirus should not be given after 6 months

 

Rotavirus vaccines are live, attenuated vaccines administered orally to protect against rotavirus infections, which can cause severe diarrhea in infants and young children. The vaccine is available in both monovalent and pentavalent forms.

 

The statement "Rotavirus should not be given after 6 months" is incorrect. The catch-up schedule for the rotavirus vaccine allows for administration up to one year of age. The vaccination schedule generally involves doses at 2 and 4 months of age, with a possible third dose at 6 months depending on the vaccine used. However, the vaccine series should ideally be completed by 8 months of age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Live vaccine: This is true. The rotavirus vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine.

 

Option B. Given orally: This is true. The rotavirus vaccine is administered orally, not by injection.

 

Option C. Found in monovalent & pentavalent variant: This is true. The vaccine is available in both monovalent and pentavalent forms, targeting different strains of the virus.

 

Educational Objective:


The catch-up schedule for the rotavirus vaccine extends up to one year of age, contrary to the incorrect statement that it should not be given after 6 months.

questions.text: A child who can make a cross, tell stories make tower of 6 cubes and goes to toilet alone, what is the age of the child: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4 years

 

Child development follows predictable patterns across various domains including fine motor, gross motor, social, language, and self-care skills. The developmental milestones of the child's age:

 

  1. Making a cross: This is a fine motor skill typically achieved around 4 years of age. A cross has four components, making it more complex than simpler shapes like circles (3 years) or vertical lines (2 years).
  2. Telling stories/poems: This language and cognitive skill emerges around 4 years of age when children develop more complex narrative abilities and can recount events in sequence.
  3. Making a tower of 6 cubes: Fine motor skills for stacking develop progressively. By 2 years, children can typically build a tower of 6 cubes (using the formula age × 3 = number of cubes).
  4. Going to toilet alone: Complete toilet independence, including managing clothing and hygiene without assistance, is typically achieved by 4 years of age.

 

While some of these skills (like building a tower of 6 cubes) may be achieved earlier, the combination of all these milestones, particularly making a cross and independent toileting, points to a 4-year-old child.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 year: At this age, children are developing basic motor skills like walking, may say a few words, and are nowhere near toilet independence. They cannot make crosses, tell stories, or build tall towers.

 

Option B. 2 years: Children at this age can typically build a tower of 6 cubes, but cannot yet draw crosses, tell coherent stories, or manage toileting independently.

 

Option C. 3 years: Three-year-olds may be developing toilet skills but typically still need some assistance. They can usually draw circles but not yet crosses, and their storytelling abilities are still developing.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The developmental milestones of a 4-year-old child, including the ability to draw a cross, tell stories, build a tower of 6 cubes, and achieve complete toilet independence.

choices.text: Profound feelings of guilt over trivial events

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of melancholia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sleep-onset insomnia

 

Melancholia, also known as melancholic depression, is a severe form of major depressive disorder characterized by specific symptoms. Key features of melancholia include:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Severe anhedonia (a loss of pleasure in virtually all or almost all activities)

 

Option B. Weight loss

 

Option D. Profound feelings of guilt, often over minor or even imagined misdeeds.

 

The characteristic sleep disturbance in melancholia is early morning awakening, not sleep-onset insomnia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Melancholic depression refers to a depression characterized by severe anhedonia, early morning awakening, weight loss, and profound feelings of guilt. It is also associated with changes in ANS and endocrine functions, hence it is also known as ‘endogenous depression’.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 380-382

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with weight for height less than minus 1 SD & height for age is minus 2 SD. What is the best possible assessment?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic malnutrition

 

Chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, is indicated by a height for age that is significantly below the normal. According to World Health Organization (WHO) standards, a height for age that is less than minus 2 standard deviations (SD) from the median of the reference population is indicative of stunting. In this question, the child has a height for age of minus 2 SD, which points to chronic malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute malnutrition: This is typically indicated by a significant weight loss over a short period, reflected in weight for height measurements. A weight for height less than minus 3 SD from the median would indicate severe acute malnutrition, but in this case, the weight for height is less than minus 1 SD, which is not sufficient to diagnose acute malnutrition.

 

Option C. Acute on chronic malnutrition: This would be indicated if the child had signs of both chronic malnutrition (height for age less than minus 2 SD) and significant recent weight loss. However, the weight for height is only less than minus 1 SD, not indicative of acute malnutrition.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect as chronic malnutrition is clearly indicated by the height for age of minus 2 SD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic malnutrition is diagnosed when a child's height for age is less than minus 2 standard deviations from the median of the reference population, indicating stunting.

questions.text: Drug resistance is most seen with which STI? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gonorrhoea

 

Explanation:

 

  • Gonorrhoea, caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae, is known for developing significant resistance to multiple antibiotics.
  • Over the years, Neisseria gonorrhoeae has shown resistance to several classes of antibiotics, including penicillin, tetracycline, and fluoroquinolones.
  • More recently, there has been an increasing number of reports of resistance to cephalosporins, including ceftriaxone, which is currently the first-line treatment for Gonorrhoea.
  • The development of drug resistance in Gonorrhoea is largely due to the bacterium's ability to acquire resistance genes through horizontal gene transfer and spontaneous mutations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chancroid: Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, has not shown the same level of widespread antibiotic resistance as gonorrhoea. It is typically treated with antibiotics such as azithromycin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, or erythromycin.

 

Option B. Donovanosis: Donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, is relatively rare and has not shown significant issues with antibiotic resistance. It is usually treated with azithromycin, doxycycline, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

 

Option C. Syphilis: Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, is typically treated with penicillin. Although there have been some cases of resistance to macrolides like azithromycin, penicillin remains highly effective, and there is no widespread resistance to it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gonorrhoea is the STI most commonly associated with significant and increasing antibiotic resistance, posing a major challenge to treatment and control efforts worldwide.

questions.text: Which among the following is not included in the severe acute malnutrition definition? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Height for age

 

Explanation:

 

Option B) Height for age

 

Not included in SAM

  • This reflects chronic malnutrition or stunting, which is a result of long-term nutritional deficiency.
  • It does not indicate acute status and is therefore not a criterion for SAM.
  • So, this is the correct answer to the question.

 

Other Option

 

Option A) weight for height 

 

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) is diagnosed when any one of the following criteria is present:

  1. Weight-for-height/length < -3 SD (Z-score) of the WHO growth standard.
  2. Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) < 11.5 cm (for children aged 6–59 months).
  3. Bilateral pedal edema (nutritional edema) of nutritional origin.

 

Height-for-age is not part of the SAM definition.

 

It is an indicator of chronic malnutrition (stunting), not acute malnutrition.

 

Option C) MUAC <11.5 cm

 

Included in SAM

  • MUAC (Mid-Upper Arm Circumference) is a quick, field-friendly indicator used especially in children aged 6–59 months.
  • A value of <11.5 cm is diagnostic of SAM.
  • Reflects muscle wasting and fat loss.

 

Option D) Pedal oedema

 

Included in SAM

  • Bilateral pitting pedal edema, also called nutritional edema, is a sign of kwashiorkor, a form of SAM.
  • Even if weight-for-height or MUAC is normal, the presence of edema alone qualifies for SAM diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Height for age reflects chronic malnutrition (stunting), while SAM is defined by weight for height < -3 SD, MUAC < 11.5 cm, or the presence of bilateral edema

questions.text:
Which of the following cyanotic heart diseases causes increased pulmonary blood flow? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Ebstein anomaly
  2. Tetralogy of Fallot
  3. Transposition of the great arteries (TGA)
  4. Total anomalous pulmonary venous communication (TAPVC)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3, 4

 

Transposition of the great arteries (TGA) and total anomalous pulmonary venous communication (TAPVC) are both cyanotic congenital heart diseases that cause increased pulmonary blood flow.

 

3. Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA): In TGA, the positions of the pulmonary artery and the aorta are switched, which results in deoxygenated blood being circulated throughout the body. The mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood occurs, leading to increased pulmonary blood flow because the deoxygenated blood is directed to the lungs.

 

4. Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Communication (TAPVC): In TAPVC, the pulmonary veins do not connect normally to the left atrium. Instead, they connect to the right atrium or systemic veins, causing a mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. This also leads to increased blood flow to the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 4: Ebstein anomaly does not cause increased pulmonary blood flow. Ebstein anomaly involves downward displacement of the tricuspid valve, leading to decreased pulmonary blood flow.

 

Option B. 1, 2: Both Ebstein anomaly and Tetralogy of Fallot cause decreased pulmonary blood flow. Tetralogy of Fallot includes pulmonary stenosis, which limits blood flow to the lungs.

 

Option D. 2, 4: Tetralogy of Fallot causes decreased pulmonary blood flow due to the presence of pulmonary stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyanotic congenital heart diseases such as Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) and Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Communication (TAPVC) cause increased pulmonary blood flow.

questions.text: Which one among the following has the lowest risk of perinatal transmission? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rubella


Rubella, also known as German measles, has the lowest risk of perinatal transmission compared to the other infections listed. While rubella can be transmitted to the fetus during pregnancy, especially in the first trimester, and can lead to significant complications such as congenital rubella syndrome (CRS), the overall risk of transmission at the time of birth is lower than for the other infections listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus): HSV has a high risk of perinatal transmission, particularly if the mother has an active infection at the time of delivery. Neonatal herpes can result in severe outcomes, including encephalitis and disseminated disease.

 

Perinatal transmission: 25-60% with active genital lesions

Highest risk with primary maternal infection at delivery

Can cause severe neonatal herpes (encephalitis, disseminated disease)

Cesarean section recommended if active lesions

 

Option B. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV is the most common congenital infection and has a significant risk of perinatal transmission. 

Perinatal transmission: 30-40% through breast milk, cervical secretions

Can occur through birth canal or postpartum

Usually asymptomatic in term infants

More severe in preterm infants
 

It can lead to a range of outcomes from asymptomatic infection to severe neurological impairment.

 

Option D. Hepatitis B: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) has a high risk of perinatal transmission, particularly if the mother is HBeAg positive. Without appropriate prophylaxis, many infants born to HBV-positive mothers will become chronically infected.

 

Perinatal transmission: 70-90% if mother is HBeAg positive

20-30% if HBeAg negative

Occurs during delivery through blood/body fluids

Without prophylaxis, leads to chronic infection in 90% of infected infants
 

Educational Objective:
 

Rubella has the lowest risk of perinatal transmission among the options listed, though it can still cause serious fetal complications if transmitted during pregnancy.

questions.text: All are seen in Cystic fibrosis except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Biliary atresia

 

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by dysfunction of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene, which leads to impaired chloride ion transport across cell membranes. This results in thick, viscous secretions in multiple organ systems. The hallmark finding is abnormally high sweat chloride levels (>60 mEq/L). In CF, secretions become thick and sticky, causing obstruction in various organs including the respiratory tract, pancreas, and intestines.

 

The manifestations of CF include:

 

  • Respiratory issues (recurrent respiratory infections, bronchiectasis, nasal polyps)
  • Gastrointestinal problems (meconium ileus, pancreatic insufficiency with steatorrhea, malabsorption)
  • Nutritional issues (failure to thrive, fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies)
  • Bleeding diathesis (due to vitamin K malabsorption as it's fat-soluble)

 

Biliary atresia is not associated with cystic fibrosis - they are two distinct conditions affecting different systems.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Biliary atresia is not a manifestation of cystic fibrosis, while meconium ileus, nasal polyps, and bleeding diathesis (due to vitamin K deficiency) are common findings in patients with cystic fibrosis.

 

Clinical features:

 

1. Respiratory system 

 

  • Repeated URTI 
  • Chronic cough 
  • Sputum 
  • Bronchiectasis 
  • Atelectasis
  • Nasal polyp 
  • H. influenza, S. aureus are the first organisms recovered from lung secretions  
  • Mortality in cystic fibrosis is due to Burkholderia 

 

2. Genitourinary 

 

  • Azoospermia 
  • Infertility 

 

Cong. B/I absence/obliteration of vas deferens 

 

3. Intestinal 

 

  • Meconium ileus is most common disorder at birth 
  • Distal intestinal obstruction syndrome (DIOS)
  • Rectal prolapse 

 

If sweat chlorides are normal, go for nasal transmembrane potential difference

 

4. Pancreatic 

 

  • Pancreatic: exocrine insufficiency-will lead to foul smelling stool 
  • Chronic pancreatitis

 

5. Hepatic:

 

  • Focal biliary cirrhosis 
  • Prolonged neonatal jaundice 

 

6. Nutritional:

 

  • Failure to thrive 
  • Hypoproteinemia + edema
  • Fat soluble vitamin def.

 

Salt loss syndrome: 

 

Acute salt depletion + chronic metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: In a patient with non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). All the following can be used for treatment except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Streptokinase

 

In the management of NSTEMI, the focus is on antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy rather than fibrinolytic agents like streptokinase. Streptokinase is specifically used in the treatment of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) where there is a fibrin-rich thrombus completely occluding a coronary artery. NSTEMI, in contrast, involves a partial occlusion by a platelet-rich thrombus, and fibrinolytics are generally not recommended because they are less effective and could potentially increase the risk of bleeding without significant benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin: As a foundational antiplatelet agent, aspirin is used in both STEMI and NSTEMI to reduce platelet aggregation and further thrombus formation.

 

Option C. Clopidogrel: This is another antiplatelet drug that is used in the management of both STEMI and NSTEMI as part of dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) along with aspirin to provide greater protection against thrombotic events.

 

Option D. Prasugrel: Similar to clopidogrel, prasugrel is used in acute coronary syndrome (ACS) management, including NSTEMI, especially when percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is planned, due to its potent antiplatelet effects. (Prasugrel is given peri-procedurally).

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison 21e chap 118/3518

questions.text:
Which of the following increases in COPD? (INICET May 2020)

 

  1. FRC
  2. TLC
  3. VC
  4. FEV1/FVC
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 2

 

In Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), there is an increase in both functional residual capacity (FRC) and total lung capacity (TLC). These changes occur due to air trapping and hyperinflation of the lungs, which are characteristic of COPD.

 

  • FRC (Functional Residual Capacity): The volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal expiration. This increases in COPD due to air trapping.
  • TLC (Total Lung Capacity): The maximum volume of air the lungs can hold. It may be increased or remain normal in COPD due to hyperinflation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In COPD, both functional residual capacity (FRC) and total lung capacity (TLC) increase due to air trapping and lung hyperinflation.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding the tape shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

 

  1. It is called Shelter's tape.
  2. It is used to assess severe acute malnutrition.
  3. Reading of 13.5 to 14.5 cm is considered undernourished.
  4. It is useful mainly for frontline field workers.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4

 

The tape shown in the image is known as Shakir's tape (not Shelter's tape). It is a tool primarily used to assess Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) in children aged 6-59 months by measuring the Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC).

 

Key Points:

 

  • Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM): Shakir's tape is specifically designed to measure the MUAC, which is an important indicator of malnutrition. MUAC is a quick and reliable method for assessing malnutrition, especially in resource-limited settings.
  • MUAC Readings and Color Coding:
    • Red: Less than 11.5 cm, indicating severe acute malnutrition (SAM).
    • Yellow: 11.5 to 12.5 cm, indicating moderate malnutrition or risk of malnutrition.
    • Green: Greater than 12.5 cm, indicating a normal nutritional status.
  • Frontline Field Workers: The tape is especially useful for frontline field workers who are often responsible for screening large numbers of children in community settings. It is simple to use, does not require advanced training, and can quickly identify children who need nutritional intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option 1 (Shelter's tape): This is incorrect; the tape is correctly called Shakir's tape.

 

Option 3 (Reading of 13.5 to 14.5 cm): This range is not considered undernourished according to the color coding system used in Shakir's tape. A reading below 11.5 cm is considered severe acute malnutrition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shakir's tape is a tool used to assess severe acute malnutrition by measuring the mid-upper arm circumference, particularly useful for frontline field workers in resource-limited settings.

questions.text: Match the following developmental milestones: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C

 

The developmental milestones are correctly matched as given in option B -1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c.

 

Transfers objects - 6 to 7 months

 

Social smile - 1 to 2 months

 

Pincer grasp - 9 to 12 months

 

Walks 1-2 steps - 12 to 15 months

 

Educational Objective:

 

Memorize the typical age ranges for key developmental milestones in infants, such as transferring objects, social smiling, pincer grasp, and walking.

choices.text: Bag and mask ventilation with oxygen inlet
Tubing near mouth and nose
Bag and mask ventilation without oxygen inlet

questions.text: Which of the following is not a method of administering free-flow oxygen in a neonate?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bag and mask ventilation without oxygen inlet

 

Free-flow oxygen refers to the administration of oxygen without the need for positive pressure ventilation. It is typically used to provide supplemental oxygen to neonates who are breathing spontaneously.

 

  • Bag and mask ventilation with oxygen inlet: This method allows oxygen to flow freely into the mask and can provide free-flow oxygen.
  • Face mask: Using a face mask can administer free-flow oxygen effectively.
  • Tubing near mouth and nose: Placing oxygen tubing near the mouth and nose is a common method to deliver free-flow oxygen.

 

However, bag and mask ventilation without oxygen inlet does not provide a means for oxygen to flow freely. This method relies on positive pressure ventilation, where the bag is squeezed to push air (and oxygen if connected) into the neonate's lungs, not allowing for the passive flow of oxygen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bag and mask ventilation with oxygen inlet: This method allows oxygen to flow through the inlet, providing free-flow oxygen.

 

Option B. Face mask: A face mask can be used to deliver free-flow oxygen effectively.

 

Option C. Tubing near mouth and nose: This is a standard method for administering free-flow oxygen to neonates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Free-flow oxygen can be administered using methods that allow passive flow of oxygen, such as a face mask or tubing near the mouth and nose. Bag and mask ventilation without an oxygen inlet does not allow for free-flow oxygen administration.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child came with palpable purpura, arthritis, and abdominal pain. A diagnosis of IgA vasculitis was made. What is the indication for starting steroids in Henoch Schonlein Purpura?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) G.I symptoms

 

IgA vasculitis, also known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by the deposition of IgA immune complexes. The classic tetrad of symptoms includes palpable purpura (typically on the lower limbs), arthritis, abdominal pain, and hematuria. While the condition is generally self-limiting and resolves within 4-6 weeks, the presence of gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms such as severe abdominal pain, gastrointestinal bleeding, or intussusception warrants the use of steroids. Steroids help reduce inflammation and alleviate the associated GI symptoms, providing significant relief to the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palpable purpura: Palpable purpura is a common manifestation of HSP, but it does not necessitate steroid treatment. The rash usually resolves on its own without the need for steroids.

 

Option B. Arthritis: While arthritis can cause discomfort and joint pain in HSP, it is typically managed with supportive care and does not require steroids. The arthritis associated with HSP is usually transient and self-limiting.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because GI symptoms are a clear indication for the use of steroids in HSP to reduce severe pain and other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura), steroids are indicated for the management of gastrointestinal symptoms such as severe abdominal pain or bleeding.
